[h1][i]Le Mans Ultimate - A Race That Stays With You[/i][/h1]

[i]Le Mans Ultimate may not be the most realistic or the absolute greatest sim-racing title ever made — but it comes surprisingly close. What truly makes it stand out isn’t just the physics or the cars. It’s the experience. The driver-swap events are, without question, one of its finest features: the simple magic of sharing the same car with friends for hours on end, driving through virtual sunrises and real-world sunsets, sweating over every corner, trying desperately not to make a single mistake whilst pushing hard. It becomes less of a game and more of an endurance test of focus, willpower, and pure stubborn passion.

And when you finally cross that finish line and stand on the podium — whether it’s COTA 6 Hours or Spa 12 Hours — the feeling of achievement is indescribable. It sits somewhere beyond pride, beyond relief, almost beyond anything else you’ve accomplished in life. You look back at the day and night stints, the fatigue, the near-misses, the laps where you drove on instinct alone, and you realize you’ve done something remarkable. But more importantly, you’ve done it together. After a long endurance race, your friendship feels different — deeper. It’s the sort of bond you’d expect from people who’ve fought side by side, not from a racing game. Yet that’s exactly the emotional weight the experience gives you.

Like life, Le Mans Ultimate is a constant balance of risk and reward. Push too hard and you gain time, but you lose consistency. Play it safe and you might fall behind. Finding that balance teaches you something quietly profound about yourself — patience, judgement, control. The game isn’t perfect, but the way it mirrors the challenges of real life, the way it connects people, and the way it turns hours of driving into a memory you’ll never forget… that’s something truly special.[/i]

[b]A sim that may not be flawless, but is absolutely unforgettable.[/b]

It's a pretty decent sim, has several features that set it apart from the others in its category (i.e. iRacing, ACC). Still needs some extra content related to single player, which I'm sure will come along soon enough.

Only real complaint is I've found some oddities in the LMP2/Hypercar braking models with tire lock up that I'm not exactly a fan of. Usually I'll end up locking the brakes and no matter how much I lift off the pedal to leave the lock up threshold, the car just won't stop locking. I say this having seen times in the brake trace where I'm at 20% brake in a straight line and the tires are still locked up.

Unfortunately this feeling goes against every bit of me that would press the brake until lockup then back it down slightly in real life, and it makes stopping difficult everywhere except the high speed entries where the downforce enables me to do that. It's strange feeling comfortable being able to stop for Monza T1 but not for Lesmo 2.

Otherwise, is a pretty good game, I personally enjoy the GT class quite a bit because the ABS allows me to get around the odd braking feel (having the wheel shake when in the ABS engagement is nice, gives better feedback for "lockups" and I wish there was better lock feedback like that on the LMP2/Hypercars).

Good physics, good graphics, good online play. Only complaints are: offline single player portion is pretty lacking. Race weekend is your only option. It would have been nice to have a season or career mode. Online play is great, but mostly only if you have a RaceControl subscription.
Came over from ACC and have not looked back. My fav racing sim that continues to get better.

At first, I had a massive problem with force feedback and many people still do... especially with Thrustmaster wheels. However, installing old drivers sorted the problem for me, and now everything works perfectly and I can play without constantly unplugging my wheel to get it back.

As for the game itself, it's brilliant. Obviously quite limited content as game focuses on endurance racing, but that's a good thing - quality over quantity. No other finished game has its cars as well tuned in terms of physics and handling as this one.

Online shares the same "quality" philosophy—there's not a hole lot, and you can't even make your own lobby for free. However, ranked races in this game are the best "online racing" I've ever experienced. Almost everyone cares about their safety rating, as loosing it means losing access to more interesting lobbies. That's a great mechanic, although it might seem unfair when you lose points because of someone else's mistake - especially at bronze where all noobies are and comparatively, it still gets messy a lot like in every other sim game. I guess iRacing is even better for competitive online play, but I'm not into subscriptions and LMU is regarded as better sim otherwise.

As for subscriptions, technically you'd need one here too for championships, but for me, multiple endurance races that are hosted here are completely enough. You have access to them based on your mentioned safety rating, and you're mostly paired with people of similar driver rank/skill, but that varies from game to game.

Single-player racing is fine, although I'm not very impressed with the AI. For that, as well as variety and private lobbies, I prefer AMS2.

Oh, and maybe for some, it's worth adding that the game plays great with a controller too - not much worse than Gran Turismo, so you might do well in more predictable cars. You will never be as consistent as with a wheel, though, and you'll mess up much more often than with a wheel. You'll also have extra controller assists; hence, with some exceptions, controller players are often not very liked in online sim racing :P

Le Mans Ultimate is an outstanding racing title that delivers one of the most immersive endurance-racing experiences available today. The driving physics feel incredibly authentic, the force feedback is detailed and responsive, and every car behaves in a way that rewards precision and consistency. The dynamic weather and day-night transitions add a level of realism that truly elevates each race.

The sound design is powerful, the visuals are polished, and the overall atmosphere perfectly captures the intensity of real endurance racing. Whether you race solo or online, the game provides a deep and satisfying experience for both newcomers and experienced sim racers. It is clear the developers are continuously improving the game, and the progress already made is impressive.

Overall, LMU feels like the future of endurance racing sims: challenging, rewarding, and genuinely thrilling from start to finish.

As someone who recently got into sim racing, Le Mans Ultimate has completely blown me away. I’ve picked up several sim racing games to compare, but this one stands out as the most immersive by far. Multiplayer has been great too. Sure, you’ll always run into a few aggressive drivers or the occasional crash, but that’s just part of online racing in any game. Overall, the experience is smooth, competitive, and a lot of fun.

Co-op is where this game really shines for me. Racing with friends, coordinating strategies, and tackling long stints together genuinely brings you together as a team. It adds a whole new layer of excitement.

Honestly, I can’t think of anything bad to say about this game. If you’re into sim racing or even just starting like I am, Le Mans Ultimate is absolutely worth it.

It's a shame, theres so many things that arent great about the game that the things which are good about it are overshadowed, LMU could be a great simracer i could frequent a lot, but i end up growing frustrated every time i play, here's why;

## The Good
The online multiplayer works decently well. I’ve only gotten disconnected once in my entire time playing, and I could reconnect immediately. No major lag spikes or other issues to speak of. How your rank and safety rating change is explained in the post-game summary, which makes improving your racing relatively easy.    

The sounds are good. Cars sound authentic, and while some cars are a lot louder than others in the cockpit, it’s not a dealbreaker. The audio is immersive and well done.   

The FFB is decent, though maybe a bit overtuned in my experience. Curbs are extremely obvious, and so is locking or sliding. What the car is doing is pretty clear from the feedback alone.   

Graphics are serviceable and look up to date. There are some points I’ll touch on later, but overall, the visuals hold up with other games like LMU.

## The Bad
The tyre model is, in my experience, utterly terrible. Grip loss is hard to understand. Overdriving your tyres in any way makes your grip vanish completely. Locking your brakes is a guaranteed spin. Wheel-spinning out of corners usually ends in one too. Even compared to other games on the same engine, I don’t have nearly as many problems with the tyres as in LMU. I hate it, and I really hope that the developers will work on improving these tyres.

Flashing your brights is way too effective. Even with high beams being enabled by default, flashing your lights overpowers all other lights on track. Meaning someone 100 meters back can make the entire track in front of you flash, It’s completely unrealistic.

Also, flashing lights don’t seem to respect walls. If someone spams their flashers on a track with tight sections, you’ll see the flashes through walls. It’s hugely distracting and very annoying. 

## The Ugly
The game’s pricing structure is unclear at best and almost deceptive at worst. You end up paying over double the price just to get all the content they offer. Plus, there’s subscription nonsense in the game that isn’t visible on the store page before you buy. The developers basically want to charge you multiple times for content and features.

The RaceControl Pro and Pro+ subscriptions aren’t clearly explained before purchase. You’re led to believe you’re buying a complete game, but in reality, you’re only getting a fraction of it.

## The Summary
Despite decent audio, stable online play, and decent visuals, the game’s core systems, especially tire physics and lighting at night, are broken in ways that destroy my enjoyment of the game, combined with a misleading monetization model these issues make it impossible to recommend at full price, or any price, really.

If you do report anyone that isnt clearly intentionally wrecking you yourself can be subject to a ban for wasting stewards time unless you pay an extra £44 a year and race in online championships. Somehow LFM can provide this for free across a range of games but having myself bought the game plus all dlc im then asked to spend more money just to be able to actually race in a racing game. Bottom line is if you want an offline hotlapping game this is great(although it would be purely hotlapping as they still havent released any form of single player progression system despite being 6 weeks into full release). So as disappointed as i am to say this i would not recommend this game unless you have money to blow on all the extra subscriptions and time to waste by being mangled in public lobbies by clowns who face no retribution. This is not rFactor 2 successor!
Although it is built on top of rFactor 2, they turned it into a simcade game like the F1 games but with the WEC cars.
The Alpha phase actually looked promising, it was close to rFactor 2, but it went downhill since then,
1. FFB is garbage even with one of the best wheelbases on the market (Simucube 2 Pro), but the feedback is similar for people with Fanatec, Moza, VRS, etc., there is no feeling for the tires (it's like the car is floating), no feel for weight transfer, to suspension load, on the other hand you can feel useless things like road texture and sausage kerbs.
2. Very bad optimization, even with very low graphics, against AI or with a lot of people the fps start high and after a bit it wents to 40fps, maybe some memory leak issue, it makes awful experience to drive with so low fps.
3. Switching tabs while driving will create ffb peaks that can be dangerous with high torque wheelbases.
4. Reloading car textures takes almost 10s and the game stops during it, can be very dangerous if you do it while driving.
5. ffb is not reduced in pitstops, another thing that can be dangerous and the game should never be released without it.
6. replay sound is a lot higher than in car, there are some volume settings in the file but none seemed to work.
7. telemetry is very limited, only happens inside the car and it shows all yellow flags, even the ones that are happening on the other side of the track.
8. Damage is bugged, sometimes you have damage and doesn't show, other time it won't let you repair unless you crash again and you need to damage something else (if it's on the same area it will never show to repair).
9. Sound is good but it's completely useless, it doesn't translate what the car is doing, pure mimick, also draft doesn't even change the engine sound.
10. Open practice servers don't have draft.
11. Very bad Draft to Drag correlation.
12. No feeling for brake bite (again, it's like the car is floating and brake just slows down the car)
13. No way to only enable virtual mirror when all mirrors are virtual, they just work as fake mirrors, with terrible fov and requires hidden keybinds to adjust them.
14. Almost no damage model, besides the rear wing, almost nothing breaks, and even crashing at high speed gives very low damage, there are no visible netcodes because it's built as bumper car effects like Gran Turismo does.
15. There's no wind or humidity which limits the track condition variability.
16. Rain is very poorly implemented, purely a traction multiplicator, not even wet lines or kerbs have different traction.
17. Very limited camera controls, even for replay, also no way to fully disable hud for replay recording.
18. If you stop the engine cooldowns, which doesn't make any sense, it should overheat because there is no air to the intakes.
19. There's only one folder of custom setups per track, if you drive different cars, different seasons it's a nightmare to organize.
20. You can use a mix of wet and dry tires, while mix of tires is allowed in WEC, the rules states it's on or the other, not both.
21. Flat spots it's bad implemented and it's limited, after a certain point it won't get worse not matter how much you lock or slide the car, also the frequency doesn't match the tire diameter and the recover of the flat spot it's not progressive (maybe to the lack of good ffb).
22. Even disable music in audio settings, when you start the game it's always playing and it's very loud.

Not even talking about all the issues with the broken splits, latency issues, etc, of the Le Mans 24 race since it was a test.
